author: William Baldwin
title: Best ETFs: Specialized International
text:
The big player in this realm is Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets ( VWO ), a China-heavy portfolio that covers most countries not in “developed markets” funds. Conspicuous by its absence is iShares MSCI Emerging Markets ( EEM ). It fails a 0.4% expense ratio cutoff.If you want to speculate on emerging markets for a few days, EEM is a fine vehicle. Its heavy trading volume makes it easy to get in and out of positions. But if you want to own the category for a long time, EEM is just too expensive.EEM and VWO follow slightly different paths. Their portfolios overlap (big holdings in both are Tencent Holdings and China Mobil) but are not identical. You might prefer the Vanguard fund for its better results in the first seven months of 2015, but a smarter reason to prefer it is that it costs less. Performance is a sometime thing. Cost is a permanent thing. It is entirely predictable.Vanguard takes a sweep at the top of this table, with help from low expense ratios and a dose of securities lending. Its FTSE Europe ( VGK ) costs a $10,000 investor only $64 over the course of a decade. The price of its sister fund in the Pacific runs $156.You might want either an occidental or an oriental slant to your portfolio. If you want a worldwide mix in your IRA, you’d probably be better off skipping the entire specialized-foreign category in favor of something from our Diversified International ranking. A large collection of country or regional funds doesn’t make sense except in a taxable account from which losses can be harvested.Rules for the Best ETFs scorecard, and links to 13 categories of funds, can be found here .
